trans-unit.source: The Domain Name System (DNS) is used to locate resources on the internet.
trans-unit.target: The Domain Name System (DNS) is used to locate resources on the internet.

trans-unit.source: For example, when you enter a web app address in your browser, or click a link on a web page, it uses DNS to translate the domain into an IP address.
trans-unit.target: For example, when you enter a web app address in your browser, or click a link on a web page, it uses DNS to translate the domain into an IP address.

trans-unit.source: The IP address is sort of like a street address, but it's not very human friendly.
trans-unit.target: The IP address is sort of like a street address, but it's not very human friendly.

trans-unit.source: For example, it is much easier to remember a DNS name like contoso.com than it is to remember an IP address such as 192.168.1.88 or 2001:0:4137:1f67:24a2:3888:9cce:fea3.
trans-unit.target: For example, it is much easier to remember a DNS name like contoso.com than it is to remember an IP address such as 192.168.1.88 or 2001:0:4137:1f67:24a2:3888:9cce:fea3.

trans-unit.source: The DNS system is based on records.
trans-unit.target: The DNS system is based on records.

trans-unit.source: Records associate a specific name, such as contoso.com, with either an IP address or another DNS name.
trans-unit.target: Records associate a specific name, such as contoso.com, with either an IP address or another DNS name.

trans-unit.source: When an application, such as a web browser, looks up a name in DNS, it finds the record, and uses whatever it points to as the address.
trans-unit.target: When an application, such as a web browser, looks up a name in DNS, it finds the record, and uses whatever it points to as the address.

trans-unit.source: If the value it points to is an IP address, the browser will use that value.
trans-unit.target: If the value it points to is an IP address, the browser will use that value.

trans-unit.source: If it points to another DNS name, then the application has to do resolution again.
trans-unit.target: If it points to another DNS name, then the application has to do resolution again.

trans-unit.source: Ultimately, all name resolution will end in an IP address.
trans-unit.target: Ultimately, all name resolution will end in an IP address.

trans-unit.source: When you create an web app in App Service, a DNS name is automatically assigned to the web app.
trans-unit.target: When you create an web app in App Service, a DNS name is automatically assigned to the web app.

trans-unit.source: This name takes the form of <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net.
trans-unit.target: This name takes the form of <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net.

trans-unit.source: There is also a virtual IP address available for use when creating DNS records, so you can either create records that point to the .azurewebsites.net, or you can point to the IP address.
trans-unit.target: There is also a virtual IP address available for use when creating DNS records, so you can either create records that point to the .azurewebsites.net, or you can point to the IP address.

trans-unit.source: The IP address of your web app will change if you delete and recreate your web app, or change the App Service plan mode to Free after it has been set to Basic, Shared, or Standard.
trans-unit.target: The IP address of your web app will change if you delete and recreate your web app, or change the App Service plan mode to Free after it has been set to Basic, Shared, or Standard.

trans-unit.source: There are also multiple types of records, each with their own functions and limitations, but for web apps we only care about two, A and CNAME records.
trans-unit.target: There are also multiple types of records, each with their own functions and limitations, but for web apps we only care about two, A and CNAME records.

trans-unit.source: An A record maps a domain, such as contoso.com or www.contoso.com, or a wildcard domain such as \*.contoso.com, to an IP address.
trans-unit.target: An A record maps a domain, such as contoso.com or www.contoso.com, or a wildcard domain such as \*.contoso.com, to an IP address.

trans-unit.source: In the case of a web app in App Service, either the virtual IP of the service or a specific IP address that you purchased for your web app.
trans-unit.target: In the case of a web app in App Service, either the virtual IP of the service or a specific IP address that you purchased for your web app.

trans-unit.source: The main benefits of an A record over a CNAME record are:
trans-unit.target: The main benefits of an A record over a CNAME record are:

trans-unit.source: You can map a root domain such as contoso.com to an IP address; many registrars only allow this using A records
trans-unit.target: You can map a root domain such as contoso.com to an IP address; many registrars only allow this using A records

trans-unit.source: You can have one entry that uses a wildcard, such as \*.contoso.com, which would handle requests for multiple sub-domains such as mail.contoso.com, blogs.contoso.com, or www.contso.com.
trans-unit.target: You can have one entry that uses a wildcard, such as \*.contoso.com, which would handle requests for multiple sub-domains such as mail.contoso.com, blogs.contoso.com, or www.contso.com.

trans-unit.source: Since an A record is mapped to a static IP address, it cannot automatically resolve changes to the IP address of your web app.
trans-unit.target: Since an A record is mapped to a static IP address, it cannot automatically resolve changes to the IP address of your web app.

trans-unit.source: An IP address for use with A records is provided when you configure custom domain name settings for your web app; however, this value may change if you delete and recreate your web app, or change the App Service plan mode to back to Free.
trans-unit.target: An IP address for use with A records is provided when you configure custom domain name settings for your web app; however, this value may change if you delete and recreate your web app, or change the App Service plan mode to back to Free.

trans-unit.source: A CNAME record maps a specific DNS name, such as mail.contoso.com or www.contoso.com, to another (canonical) domain name.
trans-unit.target: A CNAME record maps a specific DNS name, such as mail.contoso.com or www.contoso.com, to another (canonical) domain name.

trans-unit.source: In the case of App Service Web Apps, the canonical domain name is the <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net domain name of your web app.
trans-unit.target: In the case of App Service Web Apps, the canonical domain name is the <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net domain name of your web app.

trans-unit.source: Once created, the CNAME creates an alias for the <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net domain name.
trans-unit.target: Once created, the CNAME creates an alias for the <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net domain name.

trans-unit.source: The CNAME entry will resolve to the IP address of your <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net domain name automatically, so if the IP address of the web app changes, you do not have to take any action.
trans-unit.target: The CNAME entry will resolve to the IP address of your <yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net domain name automatically, so if the IP address of the web app changes, you do not have to take any action.

trans-unit.source: Some domain registrars only allow you to map subdomains when using a CNAME record, such as www.contoso.com, and not root names, such as contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: Some domain registrars only allow you to map subdomains when using a CNAME record, such as www.contoso.com, and not root names, such as contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: For more information on CNAME records, see the documentation provided by your registrar, the Wikipedia entry on CNAME record, or the IETF Domain Names - Implementation and Specification document.
trans-unit.target: For more information on CNAME records, see the documentation provided by your registrar, the Wikipedia entry on CNAME record, or the IETF Domain Names - Implementation and Specification document.

trans-unit.source: Using an A record with Web Apps requires you to first create one of the following CNAME records:
trans-unit.target: Using an A record with Web Apps requires you to first create one of the following CNAME records:

trans-unit.source: For the root domain or wildcard sub-dodmains - A DNS name of awverify to awverify.<yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net.
trans-unit.target: For the root domain or wildcard sub-dodmains - A DNS name of awverify to awverify.<yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net.

trans-unit.source: For a specific sub-domain - A DNS name of awverify.<sub-domain> to awverify.<yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net.
trans-unit.target: For a specific sub-domain - A DNS name of awverify.<sub-domain> to awverify.<yourwebappname>.azurewebsites.net.

trans-unit.source: For example, awverify.blogs if the A record is for blogs.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, awverify.blogs if the A record is for blogs.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: This CNAME record is used to verify that you own the domain you are attempting to use.
trans-unit.target: This CNAME record is used to verify that you own the domain you are attempting to use.

trans-unit.source: This is in addition to creating an A record pointing to the virtual IP address of your web ap.
trans-unit.target: This is in addition to creating an A record pointing to the virtual IP address of your web ap.

trans-unit.source: You can find the IP address, as well as the awverify name and .azurewebsites.net names for your web app by performing the following steps:
trans-unit.target: You can find the IP address, as well as the awverify name and .azurewebsites.net names for your web app by performing the following steps:

trans-unit.source: In your browser, open the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, open the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the Web Apps blade, click the name of your web app, select All Settings, and then select Custom domains and SSL from the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: In the Web Apps blade, click the name of your web app, select All Settings, and then select Custom domains and SSL from the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If Manage Domains is not enabled, you are using a Free web app.
trans-unit.target: If Manage Domains is not enabled, you are using a Free web app.

trans-unit.source: You cannot use custom domain names with a Free web app, and must upgrade the App Service plan to Shared, Basic, or Standard mode.
trans-unit.target: You cannot use custom domain names with a Free web app, and must upgrade the App Service plan to Shared, Basic, or Standard mode.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the App Service plan modes, including how to change the mode of your web app, see <linkText>How to scale web apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the App Service plan modes, including how to change the mode of your web app, see <linkText>How to scale web apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the MANAGE CUSTOM DOMAINS dialog, you will see the awverify information, the currently assigned .azurewebsites.net domain name, and the virtual IP address.
trans-unit.target: In the MANAGE CUSTOM DOMAINS dialog, you will see the awverify information, the currently assigned .azurewebsites.net domain name, and the virtual IP address.

trans-unit.source: Save this information, as it will be used when creating DNS records.
trans-unit.target: Save this information, as it will be used when creating DNS records.
